name: Pharmacy/Treatment Give
description: The Pharmacy/Treatment Give segment (RXG) contains information about the planned administration of medications to patients. This segment represents the critical bridge between pharmacy dispensing (RXD) and actual administration (RXA), providing detailed instructions for medication giving. The RXG segment is essential for medication administration workflows, specifying what should be given to the patient, when, how, and by whom. It supports complex medication administration scenarios including IV infusions, PRN medications, and multi-dose regimens in hospital and clinical settings.

cardinality.note: Multiple RXG segments can be used for different administration times or complex regimens

RXG.1.name: Give Sub-ID Counter
RXG.1.description: This field contains a sequence number that identifies this particular 'give' instruction within a series of gives for the same medication order.
RXG.1.generationHint: Sequential numbering: 1, 2, 3, etc. for multiple administration times

RXG.2.name: Dispense Sub-ID Counter
RXG.2.description: This field contains a sequence number that identifies which dispense event this give instruction is associated with.
RXG.2.generationHint: Links to corresponding RXD segment for traceability

RXG.3.name: Quantity/Timing
RXG.3.description: This field specifies when and how much medication should be given, including dose timing and frequency instructions.
RXG.3.generationHint: Timing patterns like Q6H, BID, PRN, or specific times like 0800-1200-1800-2200

RXG.4.name: Give Code
RXG.4.description: This field contains the medication code for what should be given to the patient. Should use standard medication coding systems.
RXG.4.generationHint: Use NDC codes for specific products, RxNorm for generic concepts

RXG.5.name: Give Amount - Minimum
RXG.5.description: This field contains the minimum amount of medication that should be given in this administration.
RXG.5.generationHint: Numeric dose amount: 1, 2.5, 10, etc. matching the prescribed dose

RXG.6.name: Give Amount - Maximum
RXG.6.description: This field contains the maximum amount of medication that should be given in this administration, if different from minimum.
RXG.6.generationHint: Used for PRN medications or sliding scale dosing

RXG.7.name: Give Units
RXG.7.description: This field specifies the units for the give amount (tablets, mL, mg, units, etc.).
RXG.7.generationHint: Should match the dispense units and be clinically appropriate

RXG.8.name: Give Dosage Form
RXG.8.description: This field describes the physical form of the medication to be given.
RXG.8.generationHint: Should match the physical form that will be administered

RXG.9.name: Administration Notes
RXG.9.description: This field contains free text notes and special instructions for medication administration.
RXG.9.generationHint: Special instructions like 'Give with food', 'Slow IV push', 'Check blood pressure before giving'

RXG.10.name: Substitution Status
RXG.10.description: This field indicates whether substitution is allowed for this give instruction.
RXG.10.generationHint: N for brand-specific orders, Y for generic equivalents allowed

RXG.11.name: Dispense-to Location
RXG.11.description: This field identifies where the medication should be delivered for administration.
RXG.11.generationHint: Room number, nursing unit, or care area where administration will occur

RXG.12.name: Needs Human Review
RXG.12.description: This field indicates whether this give instruction requires human review before administration.
RXG.12.generationHint: Y for high-risk medications, complex dosing, or patient-specific considerations

RXG.13.name: Pharmacy/Treatment Supplier's Special Administration Instructions
RXG.13.description: This field contains special administration instructions provided by the pharmacy or treatment supplier.
RXG.13.generationHint: Pharmacy-specific instructions for preparation, storage, or administration techniques

RXG.14.name: Give Per (Time Unit)
RXG.14.description: This field specifies the time unit over which the give amount should be administered.
RXG.14.generationHint: HR for infusions, DAY for daily medications, DOSE for single administrations

RXG.15.name: Give Rate Amount
RXG.15.description: This field contains the rate at which the medication should be given (for infusions and continuous medications).

RXG.16.name: Give Rate Units
RXG.16.description: This field specifies the units for the give rate amount.
RXG.16.generationHint: Should match the give rate amount and be clinically appropriate for the medication

RXG.17.name: Give Strength
RXG.17.description: This field contains the strength or concentration of the medication to be given.
RXG.17.generationHint: Concentration: 10, 25, 100, etc. paired with strength units

RXG.18.name: Give Strength Units
RXG.18.description: This field specifies the units for the give strength.
RXG.18.generationHint: Should describe the concentration of active ingredient in the dosage form

RXG.19.name: Substance Lot Number
RXG.19.description: This field contains the lot number of the medication substance to be given.
RXG.19.generationHint: Manufacturer lot number for tracking and recall purposes

RXG.20.name: Substance Expiration Date
RXG.20.description: This field contains the expiration date of the medication substance to be given.
RXG.20.generationHint: Expiration date for medication safety and effectiveness

RXG.21.name: Substance Manufacturer Name
RXG.21.description: This field contains the name of the manufacturer of the medication substance to be given.
RXG.21.generationHint: Manufacturer information for quality control and safety tracking

RXG.22.name: Indication
RXG.22.description: This field contains the medical indication or reason for giving this medication.

validValues.description: Anoxic brain damage, not elsewhere classified

RXG.22.generationHint: ICD-10 codes for specific diagnoses, or common terms for symptoms

notes: RXG segment bridges pharmacy dispensing and nursing administration workflows
Give Sub-ID Counter (RXG.1) and Give Code (RXG.4), Give Amount (RXG.5), Give Units (RXG.7) are required
Critical for medication administration record (MAR) generation and nursing workflows
Supports complex administration scenarios including infusions, PRN medications, and sliding scales
Integration with automated dispensing cabinets and smart pump technology
Essential for medication safety through barcode scanning and clinical decision support

dataConsistency.doseUnitAlignment: Give amount should be compatible with give units and dosage form
dataConsistency.rateCalculation: Give rate amount and units should be mathematically consistent with dose
dataConsistency.timingValidation: Quantity/timing should align with clinical appropriateness for the medication
dataConsistency.strengthConsistency: Give strength should match the medication code concentration

businessRules.medicationSafety: High-alert medications should require human review (RXG.12 = Y)
businessRules.infusionValidation: IV medications should have appropriate rate specifications
businessRules.prnRequirements: PRN medications should have clear administration criteria in notes
businessRules.controlledSubstances: Controlled substances require enhanced tracking and documentation
businessRules.allergyChecking: Medication codes should be validated against patient allergy profiles
